de.susebox.java.lang

Interface Environment

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    DefaultEnvironment

    public interface Environment

    A Environment object is a substitute for the usual environment as defined in the System class, most important the stdin and stdout channels System.in and System.out.

    Environments are especially useful in classes that can be used both standalone (having a main method) or in an application where the class is only one of many. Another scenario would be a simple class designed for use from the command line that should suddenly be invoked in GUI framework without redirecting the default channels System.in and System.out.

    To obtain an Environment instance or to store such instances use the class EnvironmentProvider: 

        Environment env = EnvironmentProvider.getEnvironment(this);

    Author:
    Heiko Blau

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      This method returns the substitution for System.err, the standard error channel.

    • Method Detail

      • in

        java.io.InputStream in()
                throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        This method returns the substitution for System.in, the standard input channel. Instead of a public member like in the System class, we prefer the method version since it is more flexible.
        Returns:
        the InputStream that serves as standard input
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if there is no stdin channel available
        See Also:
        System.in

      • out

        java.io.PrintStream out()
                 throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        This method returns the substitution for System.out, the standard output channel. Instead of a public member like in the System class, we prefer the method version since it is more flexible.
        Returns:
        the PrintStream that serves as standard output
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if there is no stdout channel available
        See Also:
        System.out

      • err

        java.io.PrintStream err()
                 throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        This method returns the substitution for System.err, the standard error channel. Instead of a public member like in the System class, we prefer the method version since it is more flexible.
        Returns:
        the PrintStream that serves as standard error output
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if there is no stderr channel available
        See Also:
        System.err

      • setExitStatus

        void setExitStatus(int status)
        During different stages of program execution various exit codes can be set using this method. For instance, a program may set the exit code to a positive number indicating that it is still running. A negative exit code may stand for errors while 0 is the usual OK code.
        Parameters:
        status - the exit code of an application
        See Also:
        System.exit(int), getExitStatus(), exit()

      • getExitStatus

        int getExitStatus()
        Retrieving the currently set exit code.
        Returns:
        the currently set exit code of an application

      • exit

        void exit()
   throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        This method exits the instance of its Environment implementation. After calling exit the Environment instance is generally not any longer usable. In particular, an implementation can choose to call System.exit(int).
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the method is not available
        See Also:
        setExitStatus(int), System.exit(int)
